headline: Tributes flow for man stabbed to death at Sunshine Coast home
who: Zdravko Bilic; Owen Jacques; Madeline Grace; Jessica; JulyWed; Zed; Bilic; Andrew Longhorn; Longhorn; Owen; Chris Toohey; Owen Jacques)Maria; Gry Tomte; linkFacebookX; StoriesAussie; Joshua Dale Brown; Epstein rowTopic; Donald Trump; David SpeersPhoto; David SpeersJust InUnemployment; Aussie; David Speers Unemployment
where: Tributes; Sunshine Coast; Warana; the Sunshine Coast; Malta; Brisbane; Make America; Albanese; China; WA
when: Monday night; 57; Monday; evening; Tuesday; morning; Wednesday; the past three years; decades; Last night; 20-hour; 11pm; Sunday; more than 24 hours; between 11pm Sunday; Yesterday; 1:32amWed 16; 20h ago20 hours; 12:39am
full_text: Tributes flow for man stabbed to death at Sunshine Coast home Tributes flow for Zdravko Bilic after he was fatally stabbed at Warana homeBy Owen Jacques, Madeline Grace and Jessica RossABC Sunshine CoastTopic:CrimeWed 16 JulWednesday 16 JulyWed 16 Jul 2025 at 1:32amZdravko Bilic was found unresponsive at Napalle Street in Warana, on the Sunshine Coast, on Monday night. (Supplied: Facebook)In short:Zdravko Bilic, 57, was found dead in his yard with two stab wounds to his stomach on Monday night. Zed , as he was known to his friends, is being remembered as a kind soul, who was well-loved and a joy to play soccer with.What's next?Police are urging anyone with information to come forward, particularly those with CCTV footage from the area.abc.net.au/news/sunshine-coast-warana-death-zdravko-bilic-street-closed/105537304Link copiedShareShare articleA Sunshine Coast man who was found dead in the front yard of his home is being remembered as enthusiastic, humble and helpful, and a lovely neighbour.Zdravko Bilic, 57, was discovered by neighbours on Monday evening in the yard of his Napalle Street home in Warana.Investigators have kept the street blocked since Tuesday morning.Police have confirmed he had two stab wounds to his stomach.No arrests have been made.The death of Mr Bilic, better known as Zed to his friends, has rocked his neighbourhood and social circles.Zdravko Bilic (bottom left) was a much-loved member of Sunshine Coast Supa Oldies Inc. (Supplied: Sunshine Coast Supa Oldies Inc.)Mr Bilic's friend Andrew Longhorn played with and against him in social soccer leagues on the Sunshine Coast.He said friends first realised something might be wrong when he was a no-show for a match. We all were surprised on Monday night when he didn't turn up as he said he would and always did when he said that, Mr Longhorn said. The hardest part for me, and I know for many, will be just not being able to say hello again and laugh together. Andrew Longhorn says Zdravko Bilic was always the first to offer to help, and was a kind soul . (ABC Sunshine Coast: Owen Jacques)Mr Longhorn said Mr Bilic was always a joy to play alongside. Zed was a great player, left nothing in the tank and gave it all on the field, Mr Longhorn said. [He was] solid in whichever position he played and always encouraging and friendly. Quick to crack a joke and always present in the moment. Forensic officers remained at the home on Wednesday and dusted for fingerprints. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Owen Jacques)'Not bloody fair'Sunshine Coast Detective Inspector Chris Toohey said Mr Bilic's death had shaken the usually relaxed neighbourhood. He is a community-minded person that is well-loved in the area, he said. As you can imagine, it is an extremely [distressing] time for [his wife], but the community are coming around her and doing as much as they can for her. A crime scene has been declared at the Warana address. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Owen Jacques)Maria, who asked not to be named, has lived in the area for the past three years after spending decades in Malta.She said Mr Bilic was always smiling and chatty to passers-by. It makes your day, she said. If you're a bit miserable, you walk and he gives you a smile and talks to you — very, very nice man. [He was] very humble — if you needed help, he would help you. I told my daughter he passed away and she said, 'I met him on the beach, we talked and he had such a nice big smile.' Police taped off the Napelle Street property on the Sunshine Coast after Zdravko Bilic was found dead. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Owen Jacques)Maria said she was taken aback by the news. I couldn't believe it, that was a shock, she said. Last night I was thinking of him — it's not bloody fair, is it? 'Zed' might have disturbed break-inSunshine Coast Detective Inspector Chris Toohey said Mr Bilic's wife, Gry Tomte, was not home at the time of the attack.She has now returned to the beachside suburb. His wife hadn't heard from him and inquired with the neighbour, who discovered him deceased, Inspector Toohey said.Zdravko Bilic with his wife, Gry Tomte. (Supplied: Facebook)Police believe there is a 20-hour window in which the attack could have occurred, from 11pm on Sunday to when he was found.Investigators also suspect Mr Bilic may have disturbed someone trying to break into the home. One of the lines of inquiry is that he has disturbed a break-and-enter, and we will continue follow that, Inspector Toohey said.The street has been closed for more than 24 hours. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Madeline Grace)State homicide squad arrivesForensic officers remained at the scene on Wednesday, and could be seen dusting two parked cars at the home for fingerprints.Acting commissioner Shane Chelepy told ABC on the state homicide squad had been sent to support the investigation. We've deployed all the available resources to investigate that as quickly as possible, he said.He declined to give further detail on police progress, saying it could compromise the case .Police taped off a portion of the street and barred traffic on Tuesday morning as forensic teams began combing the area for evidence and detectives interviewed neighbours.Investigators have asked anyone with information to come forward.They particularly want to speak with anyone who has CCTV footage from the area between 11pm Sunday and 7:35pm Monday.ABC Sunshine — local news in your inboxGet our local newsletter, delivered free each WednesdayEmail addressSubscribeYour information is being handled in accordance with the ABC Privacy Collection Statement.Posted Yesterday at 1:32amWed 16 Jul 2025 at 1:32am, updated 20h ago20 hours agoWed 16 Jul 2025 at 5:20amShare optionsCopy linkFacebookX (formerly Twitter)Top StoriesAussie dollar falls as unemployment unexpectedly risesLIVEPhoto shows A number of people cross an intersection in Brisbane's CBD. headline: Men charged after almost 600kg of meth concealed in 'kilometres' of fabric
who: JulyWed; Bowen Hills; Tony Nguyen; Ky Brendan; Martin Nguyen; James Copeman; AFP)He; Copeman; Superintendent Telfer; StoriesAussie; Joshua Dale Brown; Epstein rowTopic; Donald Trump; David SpeersPhoto; David SpeersJust InUnemployment; Aussie; David Speers Unemployment
where: meth; Queensland; Thailand; Bowen Hills; Brisbane; Australia; New South Wales; Make America; Albanese; China; Sunshine Coast; WA
when: July 4; 24-year-old; 22; 24; 28; Wednesday; August; every minute; Yesterday; 1:08amWed 16; 21h; hours; 12:39am
full_text: Men charged after almost 600kg of meth concealed in 'kilometres' of fabric Three men charged over alleged roles in importation of methamphetamine from ThailandBy Claudia WilliamsTopic:CrimeWed 16 JulWednesday 16 JulyWed 16 Jul 2025 at 1:08amIt is alleged the drugs were concealed in eight wooden crates declared as UV protective fabrics. (Supplied: AFP)abc.net.au/news/methamphetamine-allegedly-concealed-fabric-port-of-brisbane/105537214Link copiedShareShare articleThree men have been charged for their alleged roles in importing almost 600 kilograms of methamphetamine concealed in kilometres of fabric.Australian Border Force (ABF) officers in Queensland intercepted a sea cargo consignment from Thailand on July 4, after it arrived at the Port of Brisbane.It is alleged the drugs were concealed in eight wooden crates declared as UV protective fabrics .Forensic testing found the shipment contained 597kg of methamphetamine wrapped inside 200 rolls of fabric, authorities say.The drugs were removed and the consignment was delivered to a warehouse in Bowen Hills. (Supplied: AFP)The drugs were removed from the consignment which was delivered to a warehouse in Bowen Hills, in Brisbane's inner north.Australian Federal Police allege the three men were in the vicinity of the warehouse when it was delivered. Two of the men allegedly began to unravel the rolls of fabric, as the 24-year-old attended a business to buy an electronic scale to allegedly weigh the illicit drugs they were expecting, ABF and AFP said in a joint statement.Police said that during subsequent search warrants of the warehouse and two vehicles, investigators found and seized the contents of the consignment, four mobile phones, about $7,000 cash, and tools suspected to be used in accessing the methamphetamine.The AFP removed the illicit drugs and the consignment was delivered to a warehouse in Bowen Hills. (Supplied: AFP)AFP Detective Superintendent Adrian Telfer said police had not ruled out the possibility of further arrests being made. Our investigation into the syndicate allegedly responsible for attempting to bring these drugs into Australia is ongoing, he said.The men, aged 22, 24 and 28, from New South Wales have each been charged with one count of attempting to possess a commercial quantity of an unlawfully imported border-controlled drug. Tony Nguyen and Ky Brendan did not appear in the Brisbane Magistrates Court when their matters were briefly heard for the first time on Wednesday.Martin Nguyen appeared via video link and applied for bail, but it was refused.All three were remanded in custody and their matters were adjourned until August.Border force officers say they uncovered 597kg of methamphetamine wrapped inside 200 rolls of fabric. (Supplied: AFP)Drugs concealed in 'kilometres' of fabricABF Acting Assistant Commissioner James Copeman said 200 metres of fabric was used for each of the 200 rolls. It is kilometres of fabric that they have used, he said. They have concealed, or attempted to smuggle, all of those smaller packages towards the end of that in the hope it would cause some sort of disruption to our x-ray technologies, of which it did not. Forensic testing found the shipment contained 597kg of methamphetamine wrapped inside 200 rolls of fabric. (Supplied: AFP)He said while concealing drugs in fabric was not a new methodology , this attempt was incredibly sophisticated . The sheer volume of methamphetamine hidden within legitimate-looking fabric rolls speaks to the lengths criminal syndicates will go to, but it also highlights the extraordinary capability of ABF officers to detect and disrupt even the most convincing smuggling attempts, Assistant Commissioner Copeman said.'Six million individual street deals'Detective Superintendent Telfer said the result demonstrated the commitment to combating transnational organised crime and illicit drug trafficking. The people behind importations like this have no regard for the harm and damage that illicit drugs wreak on the Australian community every minute of every day, he said. Methamphetamine is a devastating drug and causes harm not just to the user, but also their loved ones and the wider community. This amount of methamphetamine could have resulted in about six million individual street deals. headline: Bradley Murdoch dies 24 years after murdering Peter Falconio
who: Bradley Murdoch; Peter Falconio Bradley Murdoch; Peter FalconioBy Samantha DickTopic; John Murdoch; Rob Hutchison; Peter Falconio; Murdoch; Falconio; next?Murdoch; Bradley; Lia Finocchiaro; Joanne Lees; Joanne Lees's; Ms Lees; David Gerhaty; Wolf Creek; Joan; Luciano Falconio; Darwin; Colleen Gwynne; Ms Gwynne; Gwynne; Alice Springs; Brian Martin; Mark Grieve; Holtze; StoriesAussie; Joshua Dale Brown; Epstein rowTopic; Donald Trump; David SpeersPhoto; David SpeersJust InUnemployment; ago32 minutes; ago58 minutes; Aussie; David Speers Unemployment
what: robbery; murder; shooting; assault; kidnapping; sexual_assault; stabbing
where: Northern Territory; Northampton; Australia; Kombi; the United Kingdom; South Australia; WA; Fitzroy Crossing; Brisbane; Make America; Albanese; China; Sunshine Coast
when: 24 years; 2003; overnight; 2005; July 14; 67-year-old; 2019; 43; 2001; night; 28-year-old; Twenty-four years; the early months; 12-year-old; 2016; 28 years; the mid-1990s; two decades; This year; June; 2022; 9:14pmTuesday 15 Jul 2025; 10:22pmTuesday 15 Jul 2025; 10:22pmTue 15; 12:39am
how: the mid-1990s for shooting at a crowd
full_text: Bradley Murdoch dies 24 years after murdering Peter Falconio Bradley Murdoch dies 24 years after murdering Peter FalconioBy Samantha DickTopic:CrimeTue 15 JulTuesday 15 JulyTue 15 Jul 2025 at 9:14pmBradley John Murdoch was arrested in 2003 by police outside an Adelaide courthouse. (Rob Hutchison: AAP)In short:Bradley John Murdoch, killer of British backpacker Peter Falconio, has died overnight in the palliative care unit of Alice Springs Hospital.Murdoch, who was sentenced to life in prison for the murder in 2005, has never revealed the location of Mr Falconio's body.What's next?Murdoch's death in custody will be subject to a mandatory coronial inquest.abc.net.au/news/bradley-john-murdoch-dies-murderer-of-peter-falconio-nt/105462624Link copiedShareShare articleNotorious outback killer Bradley John Murdoch has died overnight in the palliative care unit of Alice Springs Hospital, taking key information about his murder of British backpacker Peter Falconio to his grave.Murdoch was serving a life prison sentence for the murder of Mr Falconio near the remote Northern Territory town of Barrow Creek on July 14, 2001.The 67-year-old convicted murderer was diagnosed with terminal throat cancer in 2019 and was being treated at Alice Springs Hospital.In a statement, NT Chief Minister Lia Finocchiaro said: It is disappointing for the Falconio family that this case remains unresolved and they are still without the closure they deserve. We remind the public that the reward for information relating to the disappearance of Peter Falconio has been recently increased. Murdoch was born in the small West Australian town of Northampton in 1958.His life before prison involved working as a mechanic, driving trucks and running drugs across outback Australia.He was 43 when he killed Mr Falconio.In 2001, Mr Falconio and his girlfriend, Joanne Lees, were exploring Central Australia together in what was supposed to be a memorable outback holiday.Joanne Lees and Peter Falconio during their trip to Australia. (AAP)The British tourists were travelling in a Kombi van at night along the Stuart Highway, about 10 kilometres north of Barrow Creek, when Murdoch gestured for them to pull over from his ute.Soon after Mr Falconio hopped out of the driver's seat to talk to Murdoch, a gunshot was heard.The black electrical cable handcuffs Murdoch used to bind Joanne Lees's hands behind her back. (Stringer: Reuters)Murdoch then assaulted Ms Lees, bound her wrists with cable ties and electrical tape and forced her into his vehicle.Ms Lees somehow managed to escape into nearby bushland, and Murdoch drove off into the darkness.Mr Falconio was never seen again.The Kombi van belonging to Joanne Lees and Peter Falconio. (David Gerhaty: Reuters)The 28-year-old's mysterious death ignited a wave of international media attention, partly inspiring the 2005 Australian horror film Wolf Creek.Mr Falconio's family and Ms Lees were thrust into the spotlight in both Australia and the United Kingdom, with Ms Lees subjected to particularly intense scrutiny.Twenty-four years after their son disappeared, parents Joan and Luciano Falconio still do not know what happened to his remains.Murdoch never revealed the location of the young man's body.An undated photo of Peter Falconio and Joanne Lees that was shown during the trial at the Supreme Court in Darwin. (AAP)Catching a killerDuring the early months of the police investigation, when hundreds of suspects were still being treated as persons of interest, there was a major breakthrough — a man reported he knew who did it.He gave the name of Bradley John Murdoch.Police moved quickly and took a DNA sample from Murdoch, who had been arrested in South Australia over allegations he abducted and raped a 12-year-old girl and her mother.The Crown case rested on Ms Lees's ability to identify Murdoch from photographs, as well as DNA evidence linking him to the crime using a blood sample taken from the scene.A police mugshot of Bradley John Murdoch. (Getty Images: Northern Territory Police)The item that ultimately condemned Murdoch was an elastic hair tie found in his ute that belonged to Ms Lees.Former NT police officer Colleen Gwynne, who was the lead investigator in the Falconio case, said an eagle-eyed police officer in her team had noticed the hair tie wrapped around Murdoch's holster while trawling through his belongings.Ms Gwynne told the ABC in 2016 that Murdoch probably didn't know how significant the hair tie was , and suggested he kept it as a trophy .Colleen Gwynne was the lead investigator on the Peter Falconio case. (Supplied)In 2005, Murdoch was sentenced to life in prison for the murder of Mr Falconio and attempted kidnapping of Ms Lees, with a non-parole period of 28 years.The court heard Murdoch had put Mr Falconio's body into his ute before dumping it somewhere between Alice Springs and Broome.During sentencing, Chief Justice Brian Martin described Murdoch's offending as nothing short of cowardly in the extreme .He said Murdoch's prospects of rehabilitation were low given his complete lack of remorse and prior offending.Murdoch was acquitted of the rape allegations in South Australia in 2003, immediately before police arrested and charged him over the Falconio case.He had also served time in jail in WA in the mid-1990s for shooting at a crowd of Aboriginal football fans celebrating a victory in Fitzroy Crossing.Bradley John Murdoch being taken to the Darwin police watch house to be formally charged with murder. (AAP)During his two decades behind bars, Murdoch always maintained his innocence.He appealed to overturn his convictions twice, but was unsuccessful.In 2016, the NT government introduced no body, no parole laws with the aim of eliciting a confession from Murdoch by removing his right to parole in 2032.It did not work.This year, NT Police launched a fresh public appeal by offering a new reward of $500,000 for information on Mr Falconio's remains.Acting Commander Mark Grieve from NT Police's Crime and Intelligence Command previously stated in June that police had been speaking to Murdoch. On all occasions, he's chosen not to positively engage with police, he said.Murdoch was transferred to the Alice Springs Correctional Centre in 2022, after previously being housed at Darwin's Holtze prison.His death in custody will be subject to a mandatory coronial inquest.Posted Tue 15 Jul 2025 at 9:14pmTuesday 15 Jul 2025 at 9:14pmTue 15 Jul 2025 at 9:14pm, updated Tue 15 Jul 2025 at 10:22pmTuesday 15 Jul 2025 at 10:22pmTue 15 Jul 2025 at 10:22pmShare optionsCopy linkFacebookX (formerly Twitter)Top StoriesAussie dollar falls as unemployment unexpectedly risesLIVEPhoto shows A number of people cross an intersection in Brisbane's CBD. headline: Jury returns verdict after seven-week 'retribution' murder trial
who: Charlie Gander; Charmaine ManuelABC SheppartonTopic; Charlie Gander's; Gander; Kylie Stott; Dimitri D'Elio; Danny Clarke; D'Elio; Stott; Mark Gibson; Gibson; May; Charlie; Bunbartha; StoriesAussie; Joshua Dale Brown; Epstein rowTopic; Donald Trump; David SpeersPhoto; David SpeersJust InUnemployment; Aussie; David Speers Unemployment
where: Bunbartha; Stott; Shepparton; Melbourne; Nathalia; Brisbane; Make America; Albanese; China; Sunshine Coast; WA
when: seven-week '; 19-year-old; December 2022; later this month; 2022; three days; Christmas Eve; seven-week; Tuesday; afternoon; 24; 37; 38; the opening days; Christmas Eve 2022; November 2022; several days; 8:34amTuesday 15; Yesterday; 12:39am
how: , murder and arson in a nearly
why: motivated by a desire for revenge
full_text: Jury returns verdict after seven-week 'retribution' murder trial Jury returns verdict for accused trio in Charlie Gander murder trialBy Charmaine ManuelABC SheppartonTopic:CourtsTue 15 JulTuesday 15 JulyTue 15 Jul 2025 at 8:34amEmergency services found Charlie Gander's body in a burnt car on a dirt road in Bunbartha. (Supplied: Gander family)In short:A Supreme Court jury has found one man guilty of murder in the trial of three people accused of murdering 19-year-old Charlie Gander in December 2022. Mr Gander's body was found by emergency services in a burnt car on a dirt road in Bunbartha, north of Shepparton. What's next?The matter will return to court later this month. abc.net.au/news/verdict-charlie-gander-stott-delio-clarke-murder-trial/105529980Link copiedShareShare articleA Supreme Court jury has found a man guilty of murdering 19-year-old Charlie Gander in 2022, after three days of deliberation.Mr Gander's body was found on a dirt road in Bunbartha on Christmas Eve after emergency services were called to extinguish a car that had been set on fire. Kylie Stott, Dimitri D'Elio and Danny Clarke pleaded not guilty to kidnapping, murder and arson in a nearly seven-week trial that heard from emergency services, DNA experts, police officers, and pathologists, and was described by a prosecutor as a case about retribution .The jury was shown photos taken by Victoria Police of the burnt car, which contained the remains of Charlie Gander's body. (Supplied: Supreme Court of Victoria)The jury delivered its verdict at Victoria's Supreme Court on Tuesday afternoon, finding D'Elio, who was aged 24 at the time of offending, guilty of all three charges.Stott, who was aged 37 at the time, in a relationship with D'Elio, and described by the prosecution as orchestrating the scheme, was found not guilty of murder but guilty of manslaughter, guilty of kidnapping and not guilty of arson. The jury found Clarke, who was 38 at the time of offending, guilty of kidnapping and not guilty of murder, manslaughter and arson. All three accused were expressionless as the verdict was read to the court.The prosecution told the jury that the trio was motivated by a desire for revenge. (Supplied: Gander family)A desire for revengeDuring the opening days of the trial, Crown prosecutor Mark Gibson said the court would hear a case about retribution and a desire to punish a person for what they believed they had done.He alleged the trio acted as a team to kidnap, kill and incinerate Mr Gander in an unnecessary, senseless and callous act.Mr Gibson told the court the alleged motive was Mr Gander's cooperation with police investigating a firearms breach by Tyson May, who was a good friend of Stott.Gander's body was found on Christmas Eve 2022. (Supplied: Gander family)Following a police raid in Shepparton in November 2022, Mr Gander gave a police interview and made a witness statement about Mr May possessing a firearm.Mr May was under a firearms prohibition order, Mr Gibson said.A disc with the record of Mr Gander's police interview found its way into the hands of others and cost Mr Gander dearly , Mr Gibson said.The court heard that Mr Gander received a copy of his police interview, which he mistakenly left behind at the accuseds' residence.Mr Gibson presented evidence to the court, including Google searches from D'Elio's phone for a dead body in burned car several days before media coverage of the death, as well as records from Stott's phone labelling the victim as Charlie dead dog Gander .As part of court evidence, the jury travelled from Melbourne to Shepparton, Bunbartha and Nathalia to view key locations in the case.A court appearance to schedule plea dates has been set for later this month.Posted Tue 15 Jul 2025 at 8:34amTuesday 15 Jul 2025 at 8:34amTue 15 Jul 2025 at 8:34am, updated Yesterday at 1:29amWed 16 Jul 2025 at 1:29amShare optionsCopy linkFacebookX (formerly Twitter)Top StoriesAussie dollar falls as unemployment unexpectedly risesLIVEPhoto shows A number of people cross an intersection in Brisbane's CBD. headline: Police union raises alarm over 'out of control' watch house conditions
who: Kumanjayi White; Kardu Rak Kirnmu; Nathan Finn; Pete Garnish; Gerard Maley; Holtze; Finn; Willis John Carlow; Michael; Pete; Darwin; Alice Springs; StoriesAussie; Joshua Dale Brown; Epstein rowTopic; Donald Trump; David SpeersPhoto; David SpeersJust InUnemployment; Aussie; David Speers Unemployment

how: the 2019 police shooting of Kumanjayi Walker
full_text: Police union raises alarm over 'out of control' watch house conditions NT police union raises alarm over death in custody risk in watch housesBy Olivana LathourisBy Samantha DickTopic:Justice SystemTue 15 JulTuesday 15 JulyTue 15 Jul 2025 at 8:19amThe Palmerston police watch house is holding dozens of extra correctional prisoners. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)In short:The Northern Territory's police union president says a death or serious incident in custody is inevitable under the dangerous conditions inside the Palmerston police watch house. One recently released detainee said the women's cells were stained with period blood, while another said men had to s**t in front of everyone in cells of up to 16 people.The NT's prison population has soared to record highs in recent months, partly driven by the introduction of tougher bail laws.abc.net.au/news/nt-police-union-warns-of-death-custody-in-watch-house-conditions/105534016Link copiedShareShare articleThe Northern Territory's police union is warning a death or serious incident in custody is only a matter of time under dangerous conditions inside police watch houses.Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised that this article contains the name and image of an Indigenous person who has died, used with the permission of their family.Their caution comes amid national attention on Aboriginal deaths in custody, after the NT coroner last week delivered her inquest findings into the 2019 police shooting of Kumanjayi Walker in Yuendumu. It also follows the recent deaths in custody of Warlpiri man Kumanjayi White in Alice Springs and a senior Kardu Rak Kirnmu elder at Royal Darwin Hospital. In a statement, the NT Police Association (NTPA) said 92 detainees were kept in the Palmerston police watch house on Monday, including 76 overflow corrections prisoners.NTPA president Nathan Finn says he's worried about the safety of police officers. (ABC News: Pete Garnish) This is officially out of control, NTPA president Nathan Finn said in a statement. It's not a matter of if, but when a serious custody incident occurs. The growing pressure on police comes just four months after the NT government promised to stop housing corrections prisoners at watch houses in Palmerston and Alice Springs.Corrections Minister Gerard Maley told parliament on March 18 that all prisoners had been moved out of the watch houses and into prisons in Holtze and Berrimah. Mr Finn told the ABC he was extremely concerned by another spike in corrections prisoners held inside watch houses. It's going to end up in a situation where a police officer is hurt, or an inmate in that facility is hurt or killed, he said. We've got no contingencies if someone gets violent. If someone has a mental health episode inside that facility, it's further placing our staff at unacceptable risk. Former detainees describe unhygienic conditionsFormer detainee Willis John Carlow, who was released on Tuesday after 10 days in the Palmerston watch house, said the conditions were horrible . We had to s**t in front of everyone and there was no space, just 10 other people — 16 other people — in one space, he said. You've got to eat while they're taking a s**t so it was pretty bad. Recently released detainees say the conditions inside Palmerston watch house are horrible . (ABC News: Hamish Harty)Another former detainee, who was also released on Tuesday but wished to remain anonymous, said the women's cells were stained with period blood. You've got eight girls crammed into one cell — girls who are on their periods and are not even being allowed to have showers, she said. We're all in this room with someone else's period blood all over the sheets and it's just pushed into a pile against the wall. She said the female inmates had created a barricade of mattresses around the cell's toilet for privacy from male correctional officers walking past. You've got one blocked toilet and then one toilet that barely works and we're supposed to be drinking water from bubblers on top of the toilet, she said. There was a pregnant woman in there who had stomach pains … and for two weeks in a row was asking to see medical [staff]. A Northern Territory Police spokesperson said all watch houses were managed through strict policy, procedures and instructions . The primary consideration in relation to people in police custody is the safety and welfare of the individual, the spokesperson said in a statement. All persons in custody are provided with basic necessities and are treated with respect. Backlog in courts contributing to chaosThe NT's prison population has soared in recent months, partly driven by the NT government's introduction of tougher bail laws.Data from the NT corrections department shows 2,847 prisoners were being held at correctional facilities on Tuesday, including 1,492 at Darwin Correctional Centre. About half of those prisoners are people on remand who have not yet been sentenced or found guilty. Inside the watch house at the police headquarters in Berrimah. (ABC News: Michael Donnelly)The overflow of prisoners is playing out in the courts. More than 185 court matters were listed between just two sitting judges at Darwin Local Court on Tuesday, giving judges about three minutes on average to process each matter. Mr Finn said the NT government had failed to support its tough-on-crime agenda with appropriate infrastructure to cope with rising prisoner numbers. This government continues to beat its chest about locking up more offenders, but it has utterly failed to plan for the consequences of its own policies, he said.Mr Finn also claimed overcrowding inside watch houses was preventing police officers from making arrests. We've heard from a number of members coming through that limitations in watch house space has led to arrests not being made, he said.Gerard Maley said individuals need to stop breaking the law . (ABC News: Pete Garnish)In a statement, Mr Maley said while the government was working to expand corrections infrastructure as quickly as possible , there was no alternative to currently keeping prisoners in watch houses. Police will continue arresting those who break the law, and corrections will continue expanding capacity to ensure those who are remanded or sentenced have a bed, he said. An extra 238 beds are expected to be operational at the Berrimah Correctional Centre by mid-August. That's in addition to the more than 500 new beds in Darwin and Alice Springs that the CLP has delivered since taking office last August. A department spokesperson said correctional staff have not operated out of the Palmerston police watch house since mid-March.LoadingPosted Tue 15 Jul 2025 at 8:19amTuesday 15 Jul 2025 at 8:19amTue 15 Jul 2025 at 8:19am, updated Tue 15 Jul 2025 at 9:17amTuesday 15 Jul 2025 at 9:17amTue 15 Jul 2025 at 9:17amShare optionsCopy linkFacebookX (formerly Twitter)Top StoriesAussie dollar falls as unemployment unexpectedly risesLIVEPhoto shows A number of people cross an intersection in Brisbane's CBD. headline: NSW Police officer charged over child abuse, bestiality material
who: Chantelle Al-KhouriTopic; Ethan; Mitchell Leslie; Leslie; Imogan Hogan; Ms Hogan; StoriesAussie; Joshua Dale Brown; Epstein rowTopic; Donald Trump; David SpeersPhoto; David SpeersJust InUnemployment; ago32 minutes; ago58 minutes; Aussie; David Speers Unemployment

when: 38; September 10.abc.net.au/news/police-officer-charged-over-child-abuse-bestiality-material/105535194Link; March this year; May; Tuesday; morning; that afternoon; September 10.Posted Tue 15 Jul 2025; 12:39am
full_text: NSW Police officer charged over child abuse, bestiality material NSW Police officer charged with possessing child abuse, bestiality materialCBy Chantelle Al-KhouriTopic:PoliceTue 15 JulTuesday 15 JulyTue 15 Jul 2025 at 8:09amThe officer was allegedly in possession of potentially over 200,000 images of child abuse material. (ABC News: Ethan Rix)In short:A NSW Police officer is accused of having child abuse and bestiality material on his personal phone and laptop.Senior constable Mitchell Leslie is also alleged to have unlawfully accessed the police computer system and restricted data.What's next:Leslie, 38, has been suspended without pay, refused bail and will next appear in court September 10.abc.net.au/news/police-officer-charged-over-child-abuse-bestiality-material/105535194Link copiedShareShare articleA police officer has been suspended without pay after he was charged over the possession of child abuse and bestiality material, and for alleged misconduct.NSW Police said it began investigating reports of unauthorised access of the police computer system in March this year, before seizing the electronic devices of a senior constable in May.Mitchell Leslie, 38, was arrested on Tuesday morning and refused bail to appear at Hornsby Local Court that afternoon.It's alleged the officer had the child abuse and bestiality material on his personal phone and laptop.The prosecution told the court he was in possession of potentially over 200,000 images of child abuse material.Mr Leslie was charged with misconduct in public office, two counts of possessing child abuse material, person possessing bestiality material and three counts of access/modify restricted data held in computer.Mitchell Leslie appeared at Hornsby Local Court on Tuesday. (ABC News: Warwick Ford)'Very serious' allegationsCourt documents alleged he unlawfully accessed the confidential NSW Police Force computer policing system database and unlawfully accessed restricted data.Among allegations of misconduct, Mr Leslie has been accused of protecting his partner from being detected driving unlawfully, being complicit in his partner's brother avoiding apprehension of domestic violence offences, and misusing a police vehicle.Court documents also alleged he provided his partner with a letter on NSW Police letterhead for the Department of Communities and Justice to assist with prioritised residence relocation .The documents said he did so being outside the scope of his duty and a conflict of interest .The officer is suspended without pay and an urgent review of his employment status is underway. (ABC News: Abbey Haberecht)His barrister Imogan Hogan applied for bail for reasons including that he was receiving mental health treatment and intended to be transferred to an in-patient PTSD program.Ms Hogan raised concerns over his custody, including that he was involved in the arrests of outlaw motorcycle gang members while he was part of the Raptor Squad.The prosecution argued the allegations he faced were very serious and that releasing him on bail or imposing conditions would be a risk. Due to the unacceptable risk of further serious offending and interference with evidence and witnesses … there are significant bail concerns, the prosecution said.The magistrate refused his bail application due to the unacceptable risk .He is suspended without pay, and an urgent review of his employment status is underway.Mr Leslie will next appear in court on September 10.Posted Tue 15 Jul 2025 at 8:09amTuesday 15 Jul 2025 at 8:09amTue 15 Jul 2025 at 8:09amShare optionsCopy linkFacebookX (formerly Twitter)Top StoriesAussie dollar falls as unemployment unexpectedly risesLIVEPhoto shows A number of people cross an intersection in Brisbane's CBD. headline: Man tells court Lachlan Young planned to 'roofie' Hannah McGuire
who: Hannah McGuire; Julia BerginABC BallaratTopic; Hannah McGuire's; Young; Ms McGuire; Benjamin O'Keefe's; Ms McGuire's; McGuire; O'Keefe; Benjamin O'Keefe; Danielle McCann; Ms McCann; Jaymie McDonald; Hannah; Abby Simpson; Ms Simpson's; Ms Simpson; StoriesAussie; Joshua Dale Brown; Epstein rowTopic; Donald Trump; David SpeersPhoto; Law; David SpeersJust InUnemployment; Aussie; David Speers Unemployment
where: Scarsdale; Brisbane; Make America; Albanese; China; WA
when: 23; five-week; early 2024; April last year; 23-year-old's; Tuesday; 12 at night; the early hours; April 5, 2024; the night; the day; the hours; between 5 and 6am the morning; 7:58amTue 15; 8:00amTuesday 15 Jul 2025; 12:39am
full_text: Man tells court Lachlan Young planned to 'roofie' Hannah McGuire Man tells court Lachlan Young planned to 'roofie' Hannah McGuire and roll her down a hill in her carBy Julia BerginABC BallaratTopic:CourtsTue 15 JulTuesday 15 JulyTue 15 Jul 2025 at 7:58amLachlan Young has denied he intentionally caused the death of his former partner, Hannah McGuire. (ABC News: Anita Lester)In short:A supreme court trial has heard that the man who unwittingly helped dispose of Hannah McGuire's body thought her ex-partner Lachlan Young was planning to roofie her, put her in her car, and roll her down a hill . Mr Young, 23, has admitted to killing Ms McGuire and dumping her body, although he denies that he is guilty of her murder. What's next?The five-week trial continues.abc.net.au/news/man-tells-court-lachlan-young-planned-to-roofie-hannah-mcguire/105534552Link copiedShareShare articleThe man who unwittingly helped dispose of Hannah McGuire's body has told Victorian Supreme Court jurors her ex-partner and killer wanted to roofie Ms McGuire, put her in her car and roll her down a hill .The court heard Benjamin O'Keefe's job was to bring an extra car so Lachlan Young, on trial for Ms McGuire's murder, had a lift home.Mr Young, 23, has admitted to killing Ms McGuire and dumping her body in bushland, but denies he did so with murderous intent.He has pleaded not guilty to the young Clunes woman's murder after an offer to plead guilty to manslaughter was rejected.Hannah McGuire, 23, was found dead inside a burnt-out vehicle near Scarsdale in early 2024. (Supplied: GoFundMe)Ms McGuire's family reported her missing in April last year, and the 23-year-old's body was later found in a burnt-out vehicle at Scarsdale, south-west of Ballarat.Giving evidence on Tuesday, Mr O'Keefe, 23, told the court that Mr Young asked him to convoy with him into bushland so he had a ride home after planning to crash Ms McGuire's car with her, unconscious, at the wheel. He wanted to put her in her car and roll her down a hill … because she was leaving him and she was going to take the house and other things, Mr O'Keefe told the court. I was supposed to meet him at 12 at night on the corner and follow him in the car, then give him a lift home. Mr O'Keefe said he told Mr Young he could not do it, and tried ignoring his messages, but after a few requests, agreed. He told the court he followed Mr Young in the early hours of April 5, 2024 out to the Scarsdale location, all of which the prosecution corroborated with CCTV footage from the night.Mr O'Keefe told jurors that at no point did he see inside the vehicle Mr Young was driving.Benjamin O'Keefe told the court Lachlan Young planned to roofie Hannah McGuire and roll her down a hill in her car. (Supplied: Facebook)When the pair arrived at the Scarsdale site, Mr O'Keefe told the court Mr Young asked him what to do with the vehicle. I said, 'Dump it, don't burn it. You get in more trouble with a fire,' Mr O'Keefe said. Lachie [Young] drives off and I follow him … he drove down the road then swerved the car and crashed it into a tree. Mr O'Keefe told the court he then watched in his rear-view mirror as Mr Young used a yellow blowtorch to set the two front seats of Ms McGuire's vehicle, with her in it, on fire.Mr Young paid him $45 for his assistance.Danielle McCann was a safety officer at Delacombe Primary School where Hannah McGuire worked. (ABC News)Safety plan in placeEarlier in the day, a teaching colleague of Ms McGuire's told the court the school where she worked put a safety plan in place over fears Mr Young would find her at work.Danielle McCann, safety officer at Delacombe Primary School where Ms McGuire was an educational support worker, told the court that whenever Ms McGuire was outside with children, the school monitored entry points on CCTV, locked external doors, and ensured Ms McGuire stayed close to buildings.Ms McCann told the court the school was aware Ms McGuire had obtained an intervention order against Mr Young after he pursued her in a car, tried to run her off the road, and punched the car window. After the intervention order was served, Ms McCann said Ms McGuire continued to receive threats from Mr Young. I asked, 'Are you safe?' Her reply was, 'I don't know,' Ms McCann told the court.Other work friends of Ms McGuire's gave evidence Mr Young was horrible and disrespectful to her during their relationship, including multiple incidents where they witnessed him yelling, using expletives, and calling her fat.Ms McGuire's work friend Jaymie McDonald told the court Ms McGuire would often break down in tears over her relationship with Mr Young.The court also heard how Mr Young phoned and messaged Ms McGuire's friends repeatedly in the hours after she was killed, accusing them of hiding Ms McGuire and causing her death. When I spoke to him, he was asking me where Hannah was … he was quite accusational that I had Hannah at my house and was hiding her from him, Abby Simpson, another of Ms McGuire's work colleagues, told the court during evidence.A floral tribute at the scene where Hannah McGuire's remains were found. (AAP: Con Chronis)The court was shown Ms Simpson's phone logs, which indicated Mr Young attempted to call her dozens of times between 5 and 6am the morning Ms McGuire was killed.He also sent Ms Simpson multiple messages stating: Where the f*** is she?… F*** me, if someone has done something to her, I will end their life. The five-week trial continues.ABC Ballarat — local news in your inboxGet our local newsletter, delivered free each WednesdayEmail addressSubscribeYour information is being handled in accordance with the ABC Privacy Collection Statement.Posted Tue 15 Jul 2025 at 7:58amTuesday 15 Jul 2025 at 7:58amTue 15 Jul 2025 at 7:58am, updated Tue 15 Jul 2025 at 8:00amTuesday 15 Jul 2025 at 8:00amTue 15 Jul 2025 at 8:00amShare optionsCopy linkFacebookX (formerly Twitter)Top StoriesAussie dollar falls as unemployment unexpectedly risesLIVEPhoto shows A number of people cross an intersection in Brisbane's CBD. headline: Woman charged with murder after baby found dead in Balcatta home

full_text: Woman charged with murder after baby found dead in Balcatta home WA Police treating death of baby in Balcatta in Perth's north as 'family violence incident'By Jessica RendallTopic:CrimeTue 15 JulTuesday 15 JulyTue 15 Jul 2025 at 2:31amA baby was found dead in a home in Balcatta on Monday. (ABC News: Garrett Mundy)In short:A seven-month-old baby was found dead in a home in the Perth suburb of Balcatta early on Monday morning. WA Police Commissioner Col Blanch has described the death as a family violence incident .What's next:Police have charged a 31-year-old woman with the infant's murder. abc.net.au/news/police-release-more-details-over-death-of-baby-in-balcatta-perth/105532824Link copiedShareShare articleWARNING: This story contains details some readers may find upsetting.WA Police have charged a 31-year-old woman with murder over the death of a baby in Balcatta on Monday. Earlier, Police Commissioner Col Blanch described the death of the baby as a family violence incident , and said the scene would likely haunt first responders for the rest of their careers.The seven-month-old infant was found dead in the home in Perth's north just after 3am on Monday.Commissioner Blanch had said the baby's mother had been released from hospital but remains in police custody.WA Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the baby's family had been deeply affected by the death. (ABC News: Andrew O'Connor)He said family members were present at the time of the baby's death. There was a male, a female and a young person. This is a trauma that no one will ever recover from, the family are deeply affected. Haunting sceneCommissioner Blanch said it was a very confronting scene for first responders.If you or anyone you know needs help:Lifeline on 13 11 14MensLine Australia on 1300 789 978Suicide Call Back Service on 1300 659 467Beyond Blue on 1300 224 636Headspace on 1800 650 890ReachOut at au.reachout.comProstate Cancer Foundation of Australia on 1800 22 00 99 There would be very few cases where you would have a crime scene of such a horrific nature for our officers and for first responders involved, he said. It's something that will most likely haunt them for the rest of their careers. It's the investigation of a family violence incident, it's confined to the members of that household, he earlier told 6PR radio. 'Incredibly sad': PremierAt a media conference on Tuesday morning, WA Premier Roger Cook described the death as dreadful .WA Premier Roger Cook described the baby's death as dreadful . (ABC News: Andrew O'Connor) Our hearts go out to everyone involved in that, he said. Obviously, there's family and friends who are impacted by the information that's coming through, he said.Mr Cook thanked first responders who he said would have gone into that scene confronted by some very, very difficult circumstances . headline: Police officer describes moment he held dying colleague in his arms after ambush
who: Brevet Sergeant Jason Doig; Jaydn Stimson; Jason Doig; Michael Hutchinson; Stimson; Grant Stevens; Sergeant Michael Hutchinson; Sergeant Hutchinson; Jaydn Harley Stimson; Jadyn Stimson; Jason; Constable Rebekah Cass; Constable Cass; Brevet Sergeant Jason Doig's; Faye Edwards; Martin Hinton KC; Action Jason; Hinton; Andrew Graham; James Nash House; Graham; Carl; Lynette Stimson; Sandi McDonald; McDonald; StoriesAussie; Joshua Dale Brown; Epstein rowTopic; Donald Trump; David SpeersPhoto; David SpeersJust InUnemployment; ago32 minutes; ago58 minutes; Aussie; David Speers Unemployment

when: 15 JulTuesday 15; November 2023; 2023; Tuesday; April; 27; 39 years; today; every single day; one day; April this year; many years; earlier this year; 2:09amTuesday 15; 2:09amTue 15 Jul 2025; 5:11amTuesday 15; 13 11; 1800 551; 1300 789; 1300; 1300 22; 46; 1800 650 890QLife; 1800 184; 12:39am
how: trauma over fatal shooting of Jason DoigBy
full_text: Police officer describes moment he held dying colleague in his arms after ambush SA Police officers detail ongoing trauma over fatal shooting of Jason DoigBy Jordanna SchrieverEBy Eva BlandisTopic:ShootingsTue 15 JulTuesday 15 JulyTue 15 Jul 2025 at 2:09amLucindale police officer Brevet Sergeant Jason Doig was shot dead by Jaydn Stimson in November 2023. (Supplied)In short:Jaydn Stimson, who killed SA Police officer Jason Doig in a shooting in 2023, has been ordered to mental health supervision for the rest of his life.Sergeant Michael Hutchinson — who was also shot in the incident — said he did not hate Stimson but never wanted to see him again.Police Commissioner Grant Stevens said the shooting had had significant impact on the wider policing community.abc.net.au/news/jaydn-stimson-sentenced-for-shooting-police-officer-jason-doig/105530072Link copiedShareShare articleNursing his own wounds and cradling his dying colleague in his arms, Sergeant Michael Hutchinson has recounted the life-changing moment of being ambushed by an armed and mentally-unwell man.In a victim impact statement read to South Australia's Supreme Court on Tuesday, Sergeant Hutchinson said he had known the shooter — Jaydn Harley Stimson — since he was five.He was called to a property at Senior, near Bordertown, in November 2023 for a welfare check on Mr Stimson, which he attended with his colleagues Brevet Sergeant Jason Doig and Senior Constable Rebekah Cass.Brevet Sergeant Doig was fatally shot in the incident, while Sergeant Hutchinson was also shot twice — in the head and torso — but survived.In April, Stimson, 27, was found not guilty of the murder of Brevet Sergeant Jason Doig, and the attempted murder of Sergeant Hutchinson due to mental incompetence.The court has now ordered he be subject to mental health supervision for the rest of his life — after hearing victim impact statements from the officers, Brevet Sergeant Doig's family, the Lucindale community and SA Police.Sergeant Michael Hutchinson spoke outside court after Jadyn Stimson was sentenced. (ABC News)Sergeant Hutchinson told the court the officers were attending the property after Stimson became involved in a fight with his brother — and later returned with weapons and shot his dog. I honestly believe if your brother or father were home you would have used your firearms on them, he said.He said while searching for Stimson inside the home, the officers were ambushed and shot, with Brevet Sergeant Doig suffering wounds to his neck and chest. Despite all my efforts to save Jason, he died in my arms, he said. The guilt I carry that Jason died on my watch is something I will live with for the rest of my life. Jaydn Stimson was found not guilty due to mental incompetence. (Facebook)He said his memories of the night were haunting and that despite operations to remove pellet wounds from his body, six still remained inside.He told the court the psychological impact of the incident was ongoing and the ripple effects were far-reaching. He said while he had spent 39 years in the force he would be known for the shooting instead of the countless hours he spent serving the community.Despite this, he said he did not hate Stimson — who was nothing to me now . I hope I never see you again, he said.'It's burnt into my memory'Senior Constable Rebekah Cass told the court she was two extra steps away from being in the room when she heard the gunshots. I had no idea where the sounds were coming from, no idea where my colleagues were, no idea if someone had been shot or if I was next, she said. It turns out, if I had taken two extra steps I would have been in that room, possibly shot, possibly dead.Senior Constable Rebekah Cass was awarded for her bravery during the shooting at Senior, near Bordertown. (Supplied: SA Police) Two steps, that's all it took to change everything. The chaos, the disorientation — it's burnt into my memory. She said she entered the room to a scene which would haunt her for the rest of her life, finding Brevet Sergeant Doig on the ground and Sergeant Hutchinson crouched over. I moved forward and saw that the body on the ground was Jason. Jason was still alive, struggling to breathe — there was blood, so much blood. He was trying to speak and I told him over and over: 'I'm here, I've got you … help is on the way'. I did everything I could to keep him alive. I stayed with him and I spoke with him until his last words She said she desperately called for help on her radio when Brevet Sergeant Doig died, and checked on Stimson.Senior Constable Cass said her one regret was that she had asked the two other officers to attend the job by her side after it was tasked to her and she had unknowingly led them into a nightmare . If I had gone alone, I wouldn't be standing here today — and that thought lives with me every single day, she said. You didn't just kill a police officer, you destroyed countless lives in a single senseless moment of violence. She said it was made more difficult because it was unlikely Stimson would ever understand what he had done.Ever since the incident she said she suffered flashbacks and had changed how she lived, worked and moved throughout the world.'This was entirely preventable'Senior Constable Cass said the system had failed her colleagues by allowing Stimson to be a registered gun owner. This didn't have to happen, this was entirely preventable, she said.Sean Evans says Brevet Sergeant Jason Doig's parents are grieving. (ABC News: Guido Salazar)Sean Evans, a close family friend of Brevet Sergeant Doig read a victim impact statement to the court on behalf of Jason's mother Faye Edwards, in which she described the deep unrelenting sorrow that never goes away . No parent should ever have to bury their child and yet that is the reality that you forced upon me and his family, she wrote. I will never again hear his voice, see his smile or feel his embrace. I often wonder if you truly understand what you have done, if you think about Jason, if you think about the people left behind who will never recover from this. I hope one day you fully grasp the weight of your actions and feel the burden of that for the rest of your life. I will never forget Jason, I will never stop loving him. And I will never stop grieving. What you took from us is beyond measure. The court also heard statements from Brevet Sergeant Doig's step-father and brother.Director of Public Prosecutions, Martin Hinton KC, read a victim impact statement to the court on behalf of the Lucindale community, where Brevet Sergeant Doig was a much-valued and energetic local often affectionately referred to as Action Jason . He was always there to help … always the first to ask 'what can I do to help', Mr Hinton said.Tributes from police and other emergency services flowed for Brevet Sergeant Doig after the incident, and a life-size silhouette of the officer was erected at Lucindale in his honour in April this year.SA Police will 'carry forward his legacy'SA Police Commissioner Grant Stevens similarly told the court the impact of Brevet Sergeant Doig's death on the policing community was significant and enduring .SA Police Commissioner Grant Stevens says the incident has had a wider community impact. (ABC News: Guido Salazar) The impact of a police officer being killed in the execution of their duty is far-reaching, he said. His name will live on forever and be memorialised as a hero. SA Police will remain united in our commitment to carry forward his legacy with honour and purpose. Defence lawyer Andrew Graham told the court he had attended secure mental health facility James Nash House — where Stimson is being detained — to read the victim impact statements ahead of the hearing.He said that while Stimson had not spoken much since the incident and was limited in his articulation, he had visibly reacted when listening to the statements. After listening he said: 'I won't be forgiven, but I want to tell them I'm sorry', he said. He understands that he's unwell but he still feels responsible for what he did. He often thinks about Brevet Sergeant Doig. Mr Graham said his client had appeared in court in person rather than via video link to try and better acknowledge what was being said to him . He understands that he will be detained for many years, he said.A memorial was erected for Brevet Sergeant Jason Doig in Lucindale earlier this year. (ABC News: Carl Saville)He said Stimson's mother, Lynette Stimson, wanted to convey to the court that her heart broke for the officers, their families and the communities impacted when she learned of the shooting and was distraught and blames herself for what happened.He said Stimson had been diagnosed with schizophrenia since the incident and his recovery had been slow because he had not responded adequately to two different antipsychotic medications.He said a third medication had improved his symptoms.At the April hearing, Justice Sandi McDonald said she found Stimson mentally incompetent on the basis his thinking and judgement were profoundly affected by psychosis .At an earlier hearing, the court had heard Stimson had been diagnosed with a psychotic mental illness which was likely to be schizophrenia .Justice McDonald will formally deliver reasons for her findings on a date to be set.Posted Tue 15 Jul 2025 at 2:09amTuesday 15 Jul 2025 at 2:09amTue 15 Jul 2025 at 2:09am, updated Tue 15 Jul 2025 at 5:11amTuesday 15 Jul 2025 at 5:11amTue 15 Jul 2025 at 5:11amShare optionsCopy linkFacebookX (formerly Twitter)If you need someone to talk to, call:Lifeline on 13 11 14Kids Helpline on 1800 551 800MensLine Australia on 1300 789 978Suicide Call Back Service on 1300 659 467Beyond Blue on 1300 22 46 36Headspace on 1800 650 890QLife on 1800 184 527Top StoriesAussie dollar falls as unemployment unexpectedly risesLIVEPhoto shows A number of people cross an intersection in Brisbane's CBD. headline: Man found dead in yard may have disturbed break-in, police say
who: Jake Kearnan; Peter SandersABC Sunshine CoastTopic; Zdravko Bilic; Chris Toohey; Bilic; Zdravko Bilic's; Gry Tomte; StoriesAussie; Joshua Dale Brown; Epstein rowTopic; Donald Trump; David SpeersPhoto; David SpeersJust InUnemployment; Aussie; David Speers Unemployment
where: Sunshine Coast; Brisbane; Make America; Albanese; China; WA
when: 57-year-old; Monday night; 57; Monday; Sunday; night; 3:54amTue 15; 3:52amTue 15; 7:11amTuesday 15; 12:39am
full_text: Man found dead in yard may have disturbed break-in, police say Man stabbed to death at Sunshine Coast home may have disturbed break-in, police sayBy Madeline Grace, Jake Kearnan, and Peter SandersABC Sunshine CoastTopic:HomicideMon 14 JulMonday 14 JulyMon 14 Jul 2025 at 9:22pmA crime scene has been declared at a Warana home. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Owen Jacques)In short:A homicide investigation has been launched after a 57-year-old man was found dead at his Sunshine Coast home.Zdravko Bilic was found with multiple stab wounds in his front yard on Monday night.What's next?Police are urging anyone with information to come forward.abc.net.au/news/crime-scene-declared-as-police-investigate-sudden-death/105532138Link copiedShareShare articlePolice say a Sunshine Coast man found dead in his front yard may have disturbed someone attempting a break-in.Zdravko Bilic, 57, was found unresponsive by his neighbours at Napalle Street at 7:35pm on Monday.He had been stabbed twice in the stomach.Sunshine Coast Detective Inspector Chris Toohey said Mr Bilic was declared dead at the scene. One of the lines of inquiry is that he has disturbed a break-and-enter, and we will continue follow that, Inspector Toohey said.Inspector Toohey says Zdravko Bilic's death has shocked the community. (ABC News)Police believe Mr Bilic was attacked sometime between 11pm on Sunday night and when he found in his yard.Inspector Toohey said Mr Bilic's wife, Gry Tomte, was not home at the time of the attack. His wife hadn’t heard from him and inquired with the neighbour, who discovered him deceased, he said.Police were called to the home on Monday night. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Owen Jacques)Inspector Toohey said Mr Bilic's death has shocked the community. He is a community-minded person that is well-loved in the area, he said. As you can imagine it is an extremely [distressing] time for [his wife], but the community are coming around her and doing as much as they can for her. Police are asking anyone with information to come forward.Live MomentLook back at how ABC readers and other Australians responded to this live moment.Tue, 3:54amTue 15 Jul 2025 at 3:54amThat's where we’ll leave our live coverageThe detective inspector says the investigation is in the “very early stages”.He says police will not be releasing all the information they have at this stage.Stay tuned to the ABC for any updates to this story.Copy linkTue, 3:52amTue 15 Jul 2025 at 3:52amMan's wife raised alarm His wife hadn't heard from him, Detective Inspector Toohey says. She enquired with the neighbour, who discovered him deceased. She was concerned because she had not heard from him. Copy linkTue, 3:48amTue 15 Jul 2025 at 3:48amA 'well loved' manDetective Inspector Toohey says the man was a valued member of the community . Any death is terrible, and this has shocked the neighbours. He is a community minded person that was well loved in the area, he says. The deceased is married, and we are speaking with his wife now. headline: Alabama governor backs withholding video of officer fatally shooting Black student
who: William Peoples; Jabari Peoples; Ben Crump; Kim Chandler /; Kay Ivey; Kelvin Datcher; Wayne Harris; Homewood; J. HamptonDeon J. Hampton
where: Alabama; U.S.; Homewood; Birmingham; WVTM
when: last month; July 8; July 17, 2025; 5:33 PM EDTBy Deon; 18-year-old; June 23; Wednesday; around 9:30 p.m.; Thursday; this week
how: of officer fatally shooting Black student U.S.
full_text: Alabama governor backs withholding video of officer fatally shooting Black student U.S. newsAlabama governor backs withholding video of officer fatally shooting Black studentJabari Peoples was killed at a soccer complex in Homewood last month, and residents are demanding the release of the body camera video.Vivian Sterling, center, and William Peoples with a photo of their son Jabari Peoples during a July 8 news conference conducted by attorney Ben Crump, left.Kim Chandler / AP July 17, 2025, 5:33 PM EDTBy Deon J. HamptonAlabama Gov. Kay Ivey is supporting a state agency’s refusal to release body camera footage in the fatal police shooting of an 18-year-old Black college freshman, saying the case must first be thoroughly investigated.Ivey said she was confident “the facts will prevail” when the Alabama Law Enforcement Agency completes its investigation into the June 23 shooting of Jabari Peoples by an officer with the Homewood Police Department.“This case [is] a top priority, and I am confident they are working to efficiently get this done,” Ivey said in a statement Wednesday to NBC affiliate WVTM 13 in Birmingham.Peoples, an aspiring police detective, was killed at a soccer complex where he was sitting in his parked car with his girlfriend. An officer approached his car around 9:30 p.m. because he said he smelled what seemed like marijuana.Peoples’ girlfriend, whose name has not been released, has denied he had a gun, said family attorney Ben Crump.The officer, who has not been publicly identified, shot Peoples after he said Peoples reached for a gun in the pocket of his car door, according to the police department.Peoples was shot in the back but there was no exit wound on his body and the bullet was not found inside him, according to an autopsy conducted by an independent medical examiner hired by his family.An autopsy conducted by the Jefferson County Coroner’s Office has not been released at the request of the state law enforcement agency.The officer’s body camera video documenting the shooting has become a crucial piece of evidence as Peoples’ family and girlfriend dispute the department’s version of events. The family, local leaders and many Homewood residents are demanding that the Alabama Law Enforcement Agency release it.State Rep. Kelvin Datcher, a Democrat who represents Homewood, said withholding the video undermines public confidence in law enforcement and tarnishes the integrity of the case.“The point of having body camera footage is to ensure transparency for the community,” he said Thursday. “There’s an urgency for the family to get a look at that video.”Protesters showed up to the Homewood City Council meeting this week calling for the video’s release and threatening to boycott local businesses, with the idea that economic pressure might force leaders to change their position.“We will host sit-ins, we will hold dine-ins and vigils through downtown at the doorstep of your businesses,” the Rev. Wayne Harris told the council, according to WVTM. “Your commerce will feel our grief, and we will shut Homewood down for justice.”Deon J. HamptonDeon J. Hampton is a national reporter for NBC News.

full_text: Former FIU student found guilty of hiring hit man to kill prosecutor, FBI agent Crime Former FIU student found guilty of hiring hit man to kill prosecutor, FBI agent By Jay Weaver July 17, 2025 12:25 PM Former FIU student Anthony Frederick Brillante II, 36, was convicted of attempted murder of a prosecutor, FBI agent and others at his federal trial in Fort Lauderdale. Miami Herald A former Florida International student who is already imprisoned for threatening to kill his relatives faces more time behind bars after a jury found him guilty of hiring a hit man to murder a federal prosecutor, an FBI agent and others.Anthony Frederick Brillante II, 36, was convicted on Friday of attempted murder of a U.S. government employee, solicitation of a crime of violence and witness tampering. Brillante is expected to receive several more years in prison at his sentencing in early October before U.S. District Judge Melissa Damian in Fort Lauderdale federal court.Brillante’s criminal activity began while he was enrolled at FIU and continued after the FBI arrested him in August 2022, according to federal prosecutors Lawrence LaVecchio and Deric Zacca.Brillante was initially charged with cyber-harassing his relatives in New York, including using hundreds of phone numbers to send his cousin, her husband and their 12-year-old daughter thousands of threatening phone calls and text messages for more than a year, according to court records. Brillante, who spoofed the victims by disguising his identity as the sender, threatened to shoot them in the face and run them over with a car in the cyber messages. The investigation led by the FBI revealed that Brillante was also sending similar threatening messages to another cousin and her husband in Texas.At his first trial in 2023, Brillante was convicted of cyber-harassment charges and sentenced to nine years in prison.But just before the start of trial that October, the FBI launched a sting operation against Brillante while he was held without bond at the Federal Detention Center in Miami.On Oct. 29, 2023, Brillante met with a federal undercover agent posing as a hit man and associate of Brillante’s cellmate. Brillante recruited the agent to kill an assistant U.S. attorney, another FBI agent who was investigating the cyber-harassment case, and his relatives in New York, according to an indictment. Brillante, through intermediaries and bank transfers, paid out a total of $40,000 to execute the deadly plot, the indictment says.His criminal activity on the eve of the initial trial became the basis for additional charges, which led to Brillante’s second trial this month. The Fort Lauderdale jury found him guilty of all 22 counts in the indictment. Jay Weaver Miami Herald Go to X Email this person 305-376-3446 Jay Weaver writes about federal crime at the crossroads of South Florida and Latin America. Since joining the Miami Herald in 1999, he’s covered the federal courts nonstop, from Elian Gonzalez’s custody battle to Alex Rodriguez’s steroid abuse. He was part of the Herald teams that won the 2001 and 2022 Pulitzer Prizes for breaking news on Elian’s seizure by federal agents and the collapse of a Surfside condo building killing 98 people. He and three Herald colleagues were 2019 Pulitzer Prize finalists for explanatory reporting on gold smuggling between South America and Miami. full_text: Bahamian police investigate murder of yacht crewmember. Vessel now in Fort Lauderdale Crime Bahamian police investigate murder of yacht crewmember. Vessel now in Fort Lauderdale By David Goodhue July 16, 2025 8:23 PM Paige Bell, a South African national, was found murdered aboard a yacht on which she was a crew member, while it was docked in Eleuthera, Bahamas, July 3, 2025. The Royal Bahamas Police Force arrested her colleague on the ship with her murder. GoFundMe Bahamian authorities have charged the engineer of a luxury yacht with the murder of a crew member colleague who was found stabbed to death in the vessel’s engine room while it was docked in Eleuthera earlier this month.Bahamian police say the woman, 20-year-old Paige Bell, from South Africa, was reported missing for a short period of time before being found dead on the 142-foot yacht, Far From It, while it was in Harbour Island, Eleuthera, on July 3.Charged with her death is 39-year-old Brigido Muños, a Mexican national who also worked on the vessel, according to Our News Bahamas. Per the news outlet, a judge denied Muños’ bond, and his next court appearance is scheduled for Nov. 20. The Royal Bahamas Police Force said that Muños had “severe” wounds to his arms when they found him, and investigators think he tried to kill himself after he killed Bell. According to the ship tracking site MarineTraffic.com, the Far From It is docked at a Fort Lauderdale marina on the New River this week. Representatives from the company that books trips on the yacht could not immediately be reached for comment. Renting the yacht, which has a crew of eight and can accommodate 12 guests in its six cabins, costs between $140,000 and $165,000 a week, depending on the time of year, according to The Luxury Charter Group. It sails to destinations including the the Bahamas, the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, the Windward and Leeward Islands and all the way to north to New England, the company says. Bell’s former shipmates from another yacht, the Sweet Emocean, posted on a GoFundMe page set up to financially help her family, that she was going to celebrate her 21st birthday on July 14. “Paige was more than a teammate, she was family. Her radiant spirit, infectious laughter, and boundless compassion made an unforgettable impact on everyone lucky enough to know her. Whether it was long days at sea or quiet moments under the stars, she brought light and warmth wherever she went,” her former colleagues wrote.“In this difficult time, we want to come together to support the people she loved most, her family.” David Goodhue Miami Herald Go to X Go to Facebook Email this person 305-923-9728 David Goodhue covers the Florida Keys and South Florida for FLKeysNews.com and the Miami Herald. Before joining the Herald, he covered Congress, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Energy in Washington, D.C. He is a graduate of the University of Delaware. full_text: Two men with Florida ties charged in alleged $650 million global crypto fraud Crime Two men with Florida ties charged in alleged $650 million global crypto fraud By Antonio Maria Delgado July 16, 2025 11:45 AM Two men with Florida ties charged in OmegaPro’s alleged $650M global crypto fraud, accused of running a forex pyramid scheme defrauding thousands of investors. Two men with connections to Florida are at the center of a sweeping federal indictment unsealed last week in Puerto Rico, accused of orchestrating a massive international fraud scheme that stole more than $650 million from cryptocurrency investors around the world.Michael Shannon Sims, 48, of Georgia and Florida, and Juan Carlos Reynoso, 57, of New Jersey and Florida, were charged with conspiracy to commit wire fraud and conspiracy to commit money laundering in connection with OmegaPro, an online investment platform that prosecutors say was actually a global pyramid scheme.If convicted, Sims and Reynoso each face up to 20 years in federal prison on each count.Federal authorities say OmegaPro lured thousands of victims from the U.S., Latin America and beyond — including Florida and Puerto Rico — with false promises of extraordinary returns, up to 300% in just 16 months, supposedly through foreign-exchange trading.But prosecutors say there were no elite traders — just a sophisticated scam.“The defendants preyed upon vulnerable individuals in the U.S. and abroad, defrauding them of over $650 million by making false promises of substantial returns and that their money was safe,” said Matthew R. Galeotti, head of the Justice Department’s Criminal Division.According to the indictment, Sims and Reynoso — along with other co-conspirators — operated the scheme from 2019 to 2023 by selling cryptocurrency-based “investment packages” and claiming the funds would be managed by expert foreign-exchange traders. Instead, investigators say the money was funneled into crypto wallets controlled by OmegaPro insiders, who then laundered and concealed the funds. Both Sims and Reynoso allegedly pocketed millions.Sims is identified as a founder, consultant, and top promoter of OmegaPro, while Reynoso allegedly ran operations across Latin America and parts of the U.S., including South Florida and Puerto Rico.To build credibility, prosecutors say Sims boasted of OmegaPro’s trading prowess and promoted its so-called “elite” traders. Reynoso is accused of assuring investors that OmegaPro was fully licensed — or alternatively, that it didn’t fall under any country’s regulations.They also went to great lengths to project an image of success, hosting extravagant events around the globe, including one in Dubai, where the OmegaPro logo was splashed across the famed Burj Khalifa skyscraper. On social media, they flaunted luxury lifestyles — high-end cars, designer watches, private jets — all allegedly paid for with investor money.By January 2023, the operation began to unravel. OmegaPro claimed it had suffered a “network hack,” sparking panic among investors. Reynoso and others promised the funds would be transferred to a new platform, Broker Group — but victims say their money was never returned.“This case exposes the ruthless reality of modern financial crime,” said Internal Revenue Service Criminal Investigation Chief Guy Ficco. “OmegaPro promised financial freedom but delivered financial ruin — stealing over $650 million from everyday people and vanishing it into virtual currency.” Antonio Maria Delgado el Nuevo Herald Go to X Go to Facebook Email this person 305-376-2180 Galardonado periodista con más de 30 años de experiencia, especializado en la cobertura de temas sobre Venezuela. Amante de la historia y la literatura. full_text: Miami therapist accused of sexually assaulting two female patients: cops Crime Miami therapist accused of sexually assaulting two female patients: cops By Milena Malaver July 16, 2025 10:15 AM A Miami therapist at a women’s mental health and drug treatment facility is accused of sexually abusing two women, according to the Miami Police Department. Getty Images A therapist at a mental health and substance abuse treatment facility for women in Miami has been arrested on charges of sexually abusing at least two patients who were under his care. Miami Police say a woman in her 40s reported that Manuel Enrique Garcia, 33, began to touch her inappropriately during a one-on-one session and sexually assaulted her. Afterwards, he told her not to report what had occurred, warning her he could lose his job and she could be discharged and return to being homeless.The woman had been admitted to the facility in February during a “vulnerable depressive episode,” according to police. The assault happened sometime between February and March, she told detectives.According to Garcia’s arrest affidavit, a second victim, a woman in her 20s, told police that approximately two weeks before his Tuesday arrest, he approached her, offered her candy and asked if she needed anything from her personal belongings, which were stored in his office. Once inside, she says he pulled her into the room, kissed her and touched her inappropriately. The woman told investigators that the defendant then made a sexually explicit proposition.She feared retaliation and that Garcia might “document negative remarks in her therapy progress notes, which could potentially harm her standing in court, prevent her from being discharged from the facility, or even delay her reunification with her child,” his arrest affidavit read.A second alleged incident occurred roughly a week later. While she was in Garcia’s office making a phone call, she claims he exposed himself and initiated another coerced sexual act. She also reported that he used his cellphone to record part of the encounter.The woman told detectives that she was paralyzed by fear, particularly given the therapist’s prior knowledge of her trauma history—information she had disclosed in confidence during therapy sessions.Police say several women corroborated the victims’ accounts.Garcia was arrested on Tuesday at 4850 NE Second Ave. per his arrest affidavit. The address matches that of Concept House, a rehabilitation center specializing in addiction treatment. He has been charged with three felony counts of a psychotherapist engaging in sex with a client.He remained in custody at Turner Guilford Knight Correctional Center as of Wednesday morning.Detectives encourage anyone with additional information or experiences to contact the Miami Police Department Special Victims Unit at 305-603-6300 or 305-579-6111.
