when: seven-month-old; 31; Wednesday; the early hours of Monday morning; Tuesday; next month; 13 11; 1300 789; 1300; 1300 224 636Headspace; 1800 650 890ReachOut; 1800 22; morning; 7:06amWednesday 16; 7:06amWed 16 Jul 2025; today
how: and smile.Breaking: Trump administration
full_text: Mother ordered to remain in custody after being charged with baby's murder Perth mother appears in court after being charged with murdering her seven-month-old baby boy in BalcattaDBy David WeberTopic:CourtsWed 16 JulWednesday 16 JulyWed 16 Jul 2025 at 5:11amJacinta Beth Sells, 31, made a brief appearance in a Perth court on Wednesday. (AAP: Richard Wainwright)In short:A Perth mother accused of murdering her baby son has made a brief appearance in court. Jacinta Beth Sells, 31, is charged with murdering her infant son in a Balcatta home in the early hours of Monday morning.What's next:Ms Sells is scheduled to appear in Stirling Gardens Magistrates Court next month.abc.net.au/news/balcatta-baby-death-mother-appears-in-court/105538608Link copiedShareShare articleA mother accused of murdering her seven-month-old baby boy has wept during a brief court appearance in which she was ordered to remain in custody.WARNING: This story contains details some readers may find distressing.Jacinta Beth Sells, 31, is charged with murdering her infant son in a Balcatta home in the early hours of Monday morning.Speaking on Tuesday, WA Police Commissioner Col Blanch said it was a confronting scene for first responders.Ms Sells appeared in court on Wednesday, with Magistrate Sandra De Maio reading out the charge of murder to her, to which she nodded she understood.She looked down at the floor for much of the brief hearing, and wept towards the end.Ms Sells is scheduled to appear in Stirling Gardens Magistrates Court next month.Family violence incidentCommissioner Blanch said police will allege the death of the baby was a family violence incident , and said the scene would likely haunt first responders for the rest of their careers.WA Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the baby's family had been deeply affected by the death. (ABC News: Andrew O'Connor)He said family members were present at the time of the baby's death. There was a male, a female and a young person. If you or anyone you know needs help:Lifeline on 13 11 14MensLine Australia on 1300 789 978Suicide Call Back Service on 1300 659 467Beyond Blue on 1300 224 636Headspace on 1800 650 890ReachOut at au.reachout.comProstate Cancer Foundation of Australia on 1800 22 00 99 This is a trauma that no one will ever recover from, the family are deeply affected. There would be very few cases where you would have a crime scene of such a horrific nature for our officers and for first responders involved, he said. It's something that will most likely haunt them for the rest of their careers.At a media conference on Tuesday morning, WA Premier Roger Cook described the death as dreadful . Our hearts go out to everyone involved in that, he said.WA Premier Roger Cook described the baby's death as dreadful . (ABC News: Andrew O'Connor) Obviously, there's family and friends who are impacted by the information that's coming through, he said.LoadingPosted Wed 16 Jul 2025 at 5:11amWednesday 16 Jul 2025 at headline: Tributes flow for man stabbed to death at Sunshine Coast home
who: Zdravko Bilic; Owen Jacques; Madeline Grace; Jessica; JulyWed; Zed; Bilic; Andrew Longhorn; Longhorn; Owen; Chris Toohey; Owen Jacques)Maria; Gry Tomte; linkFacebookX; Jake; Callum Robinson; Epstein; Hannah; Sketch; Salim Mehajer; sayTopic; ago9 minutes; ago6 minutes; Geoffrey Guest; ago32 minutes
what: stabbing; murder; kidnapping; assault; cybercrime; shooting

when: Monday night; 57; Monday; evening; Tuesday; morning; Wednesday; the past three years; decades; Last night; 20-hour; 11pm; Sunday; more than 24 hours; between 11pm Sunday; 1:32amWednesday 16 Jul 2025; 1:32amWed 16; 2025; 5:20amWednesday 16; today
how: and smile.Breaking: Trump administration
full_text: Tributes flow for man stabbed to death at Sunshine Coast home Tributes flow for Zdravko Bilic after he was fatally stabbed at Warana homeBy Owen Jacques, Madeline Grace and Jessica RossABC Sunshine CoastTopic:CrimeWed 16 JulWednesday 16 JulyWed 16 Jul 2025 at 1:32amZdravko Bilic was found unresponsive at Napalle Street in Warana, on the Sunshine Coast, on Monday night. (Supplied: Facebook)In short:Zdravko Bilic, 57, was found dead in his yard with two stab wounds to his stomach on Monday night. Zed , as he was known to his friends, is being remembered as a kind soul, who was well-loved and a joy to play soccer with.What's next?Police are urging anyone with information to come forward, particularly those with CCTV footage from the area.abc.net.au/news/sunshine-coast-warana-death-zdravko-bilic-street-closed/105537304Link copiedShareShare articleA Sunshine Coast man who was found dead in the front yard of his home is being remembered as enthusiastic, humble and helpful, and a lovely neighbour.Zdravko Bilic, 57, was discovered by neighbours on Monday evening in the yard of his Napalle Street home in Warana.Investigators have kept the street blocked since Tuesday morning.Police have confirmed he had two stab wounds to his stomach.No arrests have been made.The death of Mr Bilic, better known as Zed to his friends, has rocked his neighbourhood and social circles.Zdravko Bilic (bottom left) was a much-loved member of Sunshine Coast Supa Oldies Inc. (Supplied: Sunshine Coast Supa Oldies Inc.)Mr Bilic's friend Andrew Longhorn played with and against him in social soccer leagues on the Sunshine Coast.He said friends first realised something might be wrong when he was a no-show for a match. We all were surprised on Monday night when he didn't turn up as he said he would and always did when he said that, Mr Longhorn said. The hardest part for me, and I know for many, will be just not being able to say hello again and laugh together. Andrew Longhorn says Zdravko Bilic was always the first to offer to help, and was a kind soul . (ABC Sunshine Coast: Owen Jacques)Mr Longhorn said Mr Bilic was always a joy to play alongside. Zed was a great player, left nothing in the tank and gave it all on the field, Mr Longhorn said. [He was] solid in whichever position he played and always encouraging and friendly. Quick to crack a joke and always present in the moment. Forensic officers remained at the home on Wednesday and dusted for fingerprints. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Owen Jacques)'Not bloody fair'Sunshine Coast Detective Inspector Chris Toohey said Mr Bilic's death had shaken the usually relaxed neighbourhood. He is a community-minded person that is well-loved in the area, he said. As you can imagine, it is an extremely [distressing] time for [his wife], but the community are coming around her and doing as much as they can for her. A crime scene has been declared at the Warana address. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Owen Jacques)Maria, who asked not to be named, has lived in the area for the past three years after spending decades in Malta.She said Mr Bilic was always smiling and chatty to passers-by. It makes your day, she said. If you're a bit miserable, you walk and he gives you a smile and talks to you — very, very nice man. [He was] very humble — if you needed help, he would help you. I told my daughter he passed away and she said, 'I met him on the beach, we talked and he had such a nice big smile.' Police taped off the Napelle Street property on the Sunshine Coast after Zdravko Bilic was found dead. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Owen Jacques)Maria said she was taken aback by the news. I couldn't believe it, that was a shock, she said. Last night I was thinking of him — it's not bloody fair, is it? 'Zed' might have disturbed break-inSunshine Coast Detective Inspector Chris Toohey said Mr Bilic's wife, Gry Tomte, was not home at the time of the attack.She has now returned to the beachside suburb. His wife hadn't heard from him and inquired with the neighbour, who discovered him deceased, Inspector Toohey said.Zdravko Bilic with his wife, Gry Tomte. (Supplied: Facebook)Police believe there is a 20-hour window in which the attack could have occurred, from 11pm on Sunday to when he was found.Investigators also suspect Mr Bilic may have disturbed someone trying to break into the home. One of the lines of inquiry is that he has disturbed a break-and-enter, and we will continue follow that, Inspector Toohey said.The street has been closed for more than 24 hours. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Madeline Grace)State homicide squad arrivesForensic officers remained at the scene on Wednesday, and could be seen dusting two parked cars at the home for fingerprints.Acting commissioner Shane Chelepy told ABC on the state homicide squad had been sent to support the investigation. We've deployed all the available resources to investigate that as quickly as possible, he said.He declined to give further detail on police progress, saying it could compromise the case .Police taped off a portion of the street and barred traffic on Tuesday morning as forensic teams began combing the area for evidence and detectives interviewed neighbours.Investigators have asked anyone with information to come forward.They particularly want to speak with anyone who has CCTV footage from the area between 11pm Sunday and 7:35pm Monday.ABC Sunshine — local news in your inboxGet our local newsletter, delivered free each WednesdayEmail addressSubscribeYour information is being handled in accordance with the ABC Privacy Collection Statement.Posted Wed 16 Jul 2025 at 1:32amWednesday 16 headline: Men charged after almost 600kg of meth concealed in 'kilometres' of fabric
who: JulyWed; Bowen Hills; Tony Nguyen; Ky Brendan; Martin Nguyen; James Copeman; AFP)He; Copeman; Superintendent Telfer; Jake; Callum Robinson; Epstein; Hannah; Sketch; Salim Mehajer; sayTopic; ago6 minutes; Geoffrey Guest; ago32 minutes
where: meth; Queensland; Thailand; Bowen Hills; Brisbane; Australia; New South Wales; Westfield Parramatta
when: July 4; 24-year-old; 22; 24; 28; Wednesday; August; every minute; 1:08amWednesday 16; 1:08amWed 16; 4:26amWednesday 16; 4:26amWed 16; today
how: and smile.Breaking: Trump administration
full_text: Men charged after almost 600kg of meth concealed in 'kilometres' of fabric Three men charged over alleged roles in importation of methamphetamine from ThailandBy Claudia WilliamsTopic:CrimeWed 16 JulWednesday 16 JulyWed 16 Jul 2025 at 1:08amIt is alleged the drugs were concealed in eight wooden crates declared as UV protective fabrics. (Supplied: AFP)abc.net.au/news/methamphetamine-allegedly-concealed-fabric-port-of-brisbane/105537214Link copiedShareShare articleThree men have been charged for their alleged roles in importing almost 600 kilograms of methamphetamine concealed in kilometres of fabric.Australian Border Force (ABF) officers in Queensland intercepted a sea cargo consignment from Thailand on July 4, after it arrived at the Port of Brisbane.It is alleged the drugs were concealed in eight wooden crates declared as UV protective fabrics .Forensic testing found the shipment contained 597kg of methamphetamine wrapped inside 200 rolls of fabric, authorities say.The drugs were removed and the consignment was delivered to a warehouse in Bowen Hills. (Supplied: AFP)The drugs were removed from the consignment which was delivered to a warehouse in Bowen Hills, in Brisbane's inner north.Australian Federal Police allege the three men were in the vicinity of the warehouse when it was delivered. Two of the men allegedly began to unravel the rolls of fabric, as the 24-year-old attended a business to buy an electronic scale to allegedly weigh the illicit drugs they were expecting, ABF and AFP said in a joint statement.Police said that during subsequent search warrants of the warehouse and two vehicles, investigators found and seized the contents of the consignment, four mobile phones, about $7,000 cash, and tools suspected to be used in accessing the methamphetamine.The AFP removed the illicit drugs and the consignment was delivered to a warehouse in Bowen Hills. (Supplied: AFP)AFP Detective Superintendent Adrian Telfer said police had not ruled out the possibility of further arrests being made. Our investigation into the syndicate allegedly responsible for attempting to bring these drugs into Australia is ongoing, he said.The men, aged 22, 24 and 28, from New South Wales have each been charged with one count of attempting to possess a commercial quantity of an unlawfully imported border-controlled drug. Tony Nguyen and Ky Brendan did not appear in the Brisbane Magistrates Court when their matters were briefly heard for the first time on Wednesday.Martin Nguyen appeared via video link and applied for bail, but it was refused.All three were remanded in custody and their matters were adjourned until August.Border force officers say they uncovered 597kg of methamphetamine wrapped inside 200 rolls of fabric. (Supplied: AFP)Drugs concealed in 'kilometres' of fabricABF Acting Assistant Commissioner James Copeman said 200 metres of fabric was used for each of the 200 rolls. It is kilometres of fabric that they have used, he said. They have concealed, or attempted to smuggle, all of those smaller packages towards the end of that in the hope it would cause some sort of disruption to our x-ray technologies, of which it did not. Forensic testing found the shipment contained 597kg of methamphetamine wrapped inside 200 rolls of fabric. (Supplied: AFP)He said while concealing drugs in fabric was not a new methodology , this attempt was incredibly sophisticated . The sheer volume of methamphetamine hidden within legitimate-looking fabric rolls speaks to the lengths criminal syndicates will go to, but it also highlights the extraordinary capability of ABF officers to detect and disrupt even the most convincing smuggling attempts, Assistant Commissioner Copeman said.'Six million individual street deals'Detective Superintendent Telfer said the result demonstrated the commitment to combating transnational organised crime and illicit drug trafficking. The people behind importations like this have no regard for the harm and damage that illicit drugs wreak on the Australian community every minute of every day, he said. Methamphetamine is a devastating drug and causes harm not just to the user, but also their loved ones and the wider community. This amount of methamphetamine could have resulted in about six million individual street deals. headline: Bradley Murdoch dies 24 years after murdering Peter Falconio
who: Bradley Murdoch; Peter Falconio Bradley Murdoch; Peter FalconioBy Samantha DickTopic; John Murdoch; Rob Hutchison; Peter Falconio; Murdoch; Falconio; next?Murdoch; Bradley; Lia Finocchiaro; Joanne Lees; Joanne Lees's; Ms Lees; David Gerhaty; Wolf Creek; Joan; Luciano Falconio; Darwin; Colleen Gwynne; Ms Gwynne; Gwynne; Alice Springs; Brian Martin; Mark Grieve; Holtze; Jake; Callum Robinson; Epstein; Hannah; Sketch; Salim Mehajer; sayTopic; ago9 minutes; Geoffrey Guest; ago32 minutes
what: robbery; murder; shooting; assault; kidnapping; sexual_assault; cybercrime
where: Northern Territory; Northampton; Australia; Kombi; the United Kingdom; South Australia; WA; Fitzroy Crossing; Westfield Parramatta; Queensland
when: 24 years; 2003; overnight; 2005; July 14; 67-year-old; 2019; 43; 2001; night; 28-year-old; Twenty-four years; the early months; 12-year-old; 2016; 28 years; the mid-1990s; two decades; This year; June; 2022; 9:14pmTuesday 15 Jul 2025; 10:22pmTuesday 15 Jul 2025; 10:22pmTue 15; today; minutes
how: the mid-1990s for shooting at a crowd
full_text: Bradley Murdoch dies 24 years after murdering Peter Falconio Bradley Murdoch dies 24 years after murdering Peter FalconioBy Samantha DickTopic:CrimeTue 15 JulTuesday 15 JulyTue 15 Jul 2025 at 9:14pmBradley John Murdoch was arrested in 2003 by police outside an Adelaide courthouse. (Rob Hutchison: AAP)In short:Bradley John Murdoch, killer of British backpacker Peter Falconio, has died overnight in the palliative care unit of Alice Springs Hospital.Murdoch, who was sentenced to life in prison for the murder in 2005, has never revealed the location of Mr Falconio's body.What's next?Murdoch's death in custody will be subject to a mandatory coronial inquest.abc.net.au/news/bradley-john-murdoch-dies-murderer-of-peter-falconio-nt/105462624Link copiedShareShare articleNotorious outback killer Bradley John Murdoch has died overnight in the palliative care unit of Alice Springs Hospital, taking key information about his murder of British backpacker Peter Falconio to his grave.Murdoch was serving a life prison sentence for the murder of Mr Falconio near the remote Northern Territory town of Barrow Creek on July 14, 2001.The 67-year-old convicted murderer was diagnosed with terminal throat cancer in 2019 and was being treated at Alice Springs Hospital.In a statement, NT Chief Minister Lia Finocchiaro said: It is disappointing for the Falconio family that this case remains unresolved and they are still without the closure they deserve. We remind the public that the reward for information relating to the disappearance of Peter Falconio has been recently increased. Murdoch was born in the small West Australian town of Northampton in 1958.His life before prison involved working as a mechanic, driving trucks and running drugs across outback Australia.He was 43 when he killed Mr Falconio.In 2001, Mr Falconio and his girlfriend, Joanne Lees, were exploring Central Australia together in what was supposed to be a memorable outback holiday.Joanne Lees and Peter Falconio during their trip to Australia. (AAP)The British tourists were travelling in a Kombi van at night along the Stuart Highway, about 10 kilometres north of Barrow Creek, when Murdoch gestured for them to pull over from his ute.Soon after Mr Falconio hopped out of the driver's seat to talk to Murdoch, a gunshot was heard.The black electrical cable handcuffs Murdoch used to bind Joanne Lees's hands behind her back. (Stringer: Reuters)Murdoch then assaulted Ms Lees, bound her wrists with cable ties and electrical tape and forced her into his vehicle.Ms Lees somehow managed to escape into nearby bushland, and Murdoch drove off into the darkness.Mr Falconio was never seen again.The Kombi van belonging to Joanne Lees and Peter Falconio. (David Gerhaty: Reuters)The 28-year-old's mysterious death ignited a wave of international media attention, partly inspiring the 2005 Australian horror film Wolf Creek.Mr Falconio's family and Ms Lees were thrust into the spotlight in both Australia and the United Kingdom, with Ms Lees subjected to particularly intense scrutiny.Twenty-four years after their son disappeared, parents Joan and Luciano Falconio still do not know what happened to his remains.Murdoch never revealed the location of the young man's body.An undated photo of Peter Falconio and Joanne Lees that was shown during the trial at the Supreme Court in Darwin. (AAP)Catching a killerDuring the early months of the police investigation, when hundreds of suspects were still being treated as persons of interest, there was a major breakthrough — a man reported he knew who did it.He gave the name of Bradley John Murdoch.Police moved quickly and took a DNA sample from Murdoch, who had been arrested in South Australia over allegations he abducted and raped a 12-year-old girl and her mother.The Crown case rested on Ms Lees's ability to identify Murdoch from photographs, as well as DNA evidence linking him to the crime using a blood sample taken from the scene.A police mugshot of Bradley John Murdoch. (Getty Images: Northern Territory Police)The item that ultimately condemned Murdoch was an elastic hair tie found in his ute that belonged to Ms Lees.Former NT police officer Colleen Gwynne, who was the lead investigator in the Falconio case, said an eagle-eyed police officer in her team had noticed the hair tie wrapped around Murdoch's holster while trawling through his belongings.Ms Gwynne told the ABC in 2016 that Murdoch probably didn't know how significant the hair tie was , and suggested he kept it as a trophy .Colleen Gwynne was the lead investigator on the Peter Falconio case. (Supplied)In 2005, Murdoch was sentenced to life in prison for the murder of Mr Falconio and attempted kidnapping of Ms Lees, with a non-parole period of 28 years.The court heard Murdoch had put Mr Falconio's body into his ute before dumping it somewhere between Alice Springs and Broome.During sentencing, Chief Justice Brian Martin described Murdoch's offending as nothing short of cowardly in the extreme .He said Murdoch's prospects of rehabilitation were low given his complete lack of remorse and prior offending.Murdoch was acquitted of the rape allegations in South Australia in 2003, immediately before police arrested and charged him over the Falconio case.He had also served time in jail in WA in the mid-1990s for shooting at a crowd of Aboriginal football fans celebrating a victory in Fitzroy Crossing.Bradley John Murdoch being taken to the Darwin police watch house to be formally charged with murder. (AAP)During his two decades behind bars, Murdoch always maintained his innocence.He appealed to overturn his convictions twice, but was unsuccessful.In 2016, the NT government introduced no body, no parole laws with the aim of eliciting a confession from Murdoch by removing his right to parole in 2032.It did not work.This year, NT Police launched a fresh public appeal by offering a new reward of $500,000 for information on Mr Falconio's remains.Acting Commander Mark Grieve from NT Police's Crime and Intelligence Command previously stated in June that police had been speaking to Murdoch. On all occasions, he's chosen not to positively engage with police, he said.Murdoch was transferred to the Alice Springs Correctional Centre in 2022, after previously being housed at Darwin's Holtze prison.His death in custody will be subject to a mandatory coronial inquest.Posted Tue 15 Jul 2025 at 9:14pmTuesday 15 Jul 2025 at 9:14pmTue 15 Jul 2025 at 9:14pm, updated Tue 15 Jul 2025 at headline: Jury returns verdict after seven-week 'retribution' murder trial
who: Charlie Gander; Charmaine ManuelABC SheppartonTopic; Charlie Gander's; Gander; Kylie Stott; Dimitri D'Elio; Danny Clarke; D'Elio; Stott; Mark Gibson; Gibson; May; Charlie; Bunbartha; Jake; Callum Robinson; Epstein; Hannah; Sketch; Salim Mehajer; sayTopic; ago6 minutes; Geoffrey Guest
where: Bunbartha; Stott; Shepparton; Melbourne; Nathalia; Westfield Parramatta; Queensland
when: seven-week '; 19-year-old; December 2022; later this month; 2022; three days; Christmas Eve; seven-week; Tuesday; afternoon; 24; 37; 38; the opening days; Christmas Eve 2022; November 2022; several days; 8:34amTuesday 15; 1:29amWednesday 16 Jul 2025; today
how: , murder and arson in a nearly
why: motivated by a desire for revenge
full_text: Jury returns verdict after seven-week 'retribution' murder trial Jury returns verdict for accused trio in Charlie Gander murder trialBy Charmaine ManuelABC SheppartonTopic:CourtsTue 15 JulTuesday 15 JulyTue 15 Jul 2025 at 8:34amEmergency services found Charlie Gander's body in a burnt car on a dirt road in Bunbartha. (Supplied: Gander family)In short:A Supreme Court jury has found one man guilty of murder in the trial of three people accused of murdering 19-year-old Charlie Gander in December 2022. Mr Gander's body was found by emergency services in a burnt car on a dirt road in Bunbartha, north of Shepparton. What's next?The matter will return to court later this month. abc.net.au/news/verdict-charlie-gander-stott-delio-clarke-murder-trial/105529980Link copiedShareShare articleA Supreme Court jury has found a man guilty of murdering 19-year-old Charlie Gander in 2022, after three days of deliberation.Mr Gander's body was found on a dirt road in Bunbartha on Christmas Eve after emergency services were called to extinguish a car that had been set on fire. Kylie Stott, Dimitri D'Elio and Danny Clarke pleaded not guilty to kidnapping, murder and arson in a nearly seven-week trial that heard from emergency services, DNA experts, police officers, and pathologists, and was described by a prosecutor as a case about retribution .The jury was shown photos taken by Victoria Police of the burnt car, which contained the remains of Charlie Gander's body. (Supplied: Supreme Court of Victoria)The jury delivered its verdict at Victoria's Supreme Court on Tuesday afternoon, finding D'Elio, who was aged 24 at the time of offending, guilty of all three charges.Stott, who was aged 37 at the time, in a relationship with D'Elio, and described by the prosecution as orchestrating the scheme, was found not guilty of murder but guilty of manslaughter, guilty of kidnapping and not guilty of arson. The jury found Clarke, who was 38 at the time of offending, guilty of kidnapping and not guilty of murder, manslaughter and arson. All three accused were expressionless as the verdict was read to the court.The prosecution told the jury that the trio was motivated by a desire for revenge. (Supplied: Gander family)A desire for revengeDuring the opening days of the trial, Crown prosecutor Mark Gibson said the court would hear a case about retribution and a desire to punish a person for what they believed they had done.He alleged the trio acted as a team to kidnap, kill and incinerate Mr Gander in an unnecessary, senseless and callous act.Mr Gibson told the court the alleged motive was Mr Gander's cooperation with police investigating a firearms breach by Tyson May, who was a good friend of Stott.Gander's body was found on Christmas Eve 2022. (Supplied: Gander family)Following a police raid in Shepparton in November 2022, Mr Gander gave a police interview and made a witness statement about Mr May possessing a firearm.Mr May was under a firearms prohibition order, Mr Gibson said.A disc with the record of Mr Gander's police interview found its way into the hands of others and cost Mr Gander dearly , Mr Gibson said.The court heard that Mr Gander received a copy of his police interview, which he mistakenly left behind at the accuseds' residence.Mr Gibson presented evidence to the court, including Google searches from D'Elio's phone for a dead body in burned car several days before media coverage of the death, as well as records from Stott's phone labelling the victim as Charlie dead dog Gander .As part of court evidence, the jury travelled from Melbourne to Shepparton, Bunbartha and Nathalia to view key locations in the case.A court appearance to schedule plea dates has been set for later this month.Posted Tue 15 Jul 2025 headline: Police union raises alarm over 'out of control' watch house conditions

full_text: Police union raises alarm over 'out of control' watch house conditions NT police union raises alarm over death in custody risk in watch housesBy Olivana LathourisBy Samantha DickTopic:Justice SystemTue 15 JulTuesday 15 JulyTue 15 Jul 2025 at 8:19amThe Palmerston police watch house is holding dozens of extra correctional prisoners. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)In short:The Northern Territory's police union president says a death or serious incident in custody is inevitable under the dangerous conditions inside the Palmerston police watch house. One recently released detainee said the women's cells were stained with period blood, while another said men had to s**t in front of everyone in cells of up to 16 people.The NT's prison population has soared to record highs in recent months, partly driven by the introduction of tougher bail laws.abc.net.au/news/nt-police-union-warns-of-death-custody-in-watch-house-conditions/105534016Link copiedShareShare articleThe Northern Territory's police union is warning a death or serious incident in custody is only a matter of time under dangerous conditions inside police watch houses.Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised that this article contains the name and image of an Indigenous person who has died, used with the permission of their family.Their caution comes amid national attention on Aboriginal deaths in custody, after the NT coroner last week delivered her inquest findings into the 2019 police shooting of Kumanjayi Walker in Yuendumu. It also follows the recent deaths in custody of Warlpiri man Kumanjayi White in Alice Springs and a senior Kardu Rak Kirnmu elder at Royal Darwin Hospital. In a statement, the NT Police Association (NTPA) said 92 detainees were kept in the Palmerston police watch house on Monday, including 76 overflow corrections prisoners.NTPA president Nathan Finn says he's worried about the safety of police officers. (ABC News: Pete Garnish) This is officially out of control, NTPA president Nathan Finn said in a statement. It's not a matter of if, but when a serious custody incident occurs. The growing pressure on police comes just four months after the NT government promised to stop housing corrections prisoners at watch houses in Palmerston and Alice Springs.Corrections Minister Gerard Maley told parliament on March 18 that all prisoners had been moved out of the watch houses and into prisons in Holtze and Berrimah. Mr Finn told the ABC he was extremely concerned by another spike in corrections prisoners held inside watch houses. It's going to end up in a situation where a police officer is hurt, or an inmate in that facility is hurt or killed, he said. We've got no contingencies if someone gets violent. If someone has a mental health episode inside that facility, it's further placing our staff at unacceptable risk. Former detainees describe unhygienic conditionsFormer detainee Willis John Carlow, who was released on Tuesday after 10 days in the Palmerston watch house, said the conditions were horrible . We had to s**t in front of everyone and there was no space, just 10 other people — 16 other people — in one space, he said. You've got to eat while they're taking a s**t so it was pretty bad. Recently released detainees say the conditions inside Palmerston watch house are horrible . (ABC News: Hamish Harty)Another former detainee, who was also released on Tuesday but wished to remain anonymous, said the women's cells were stained with period blood. You've got eight girls crammed into one cell — girls who are on their periods and are not even being allowed to have showers, she said. We're all in this room with someone else's period blood all over the sheets and it's just pushed into a pile against the wall. She said the female inmates had created a barricade of mattresses around the cell's toilet for privacy from male correctional officers walking past. You've got one blocked toilet and then one toilet that barely works and we're supposed to be drinking water from bubblers on top of the toilet, she said. There was a pregnant woman in there who had stomach pains … and for two weeks in a row was asking to see medical [staff]. A Northern Territory Police spokesperson said all watch houses were managed through strict policy, procedures and instructions . The primary consideration in relation to people in police custody is the safety and welfare of the individual, the spokesperson said in a statement. All persons in custody are provided with basic necessities and are treated with respect. Backlog in courts contributing to chaosThe NT's prison population has soared in recent months, partly driven by the NT government's introduction of tougher bail laws.Data from the NT corrections department shows 2,847 prisoners were being held at correctional facilities on Tuesday, including 1,492 at Darwin Correctional Centre. About half of those prisoners are people on remand who have not yet been sentenced or found guilty. Inside the watch house at the police headquarters in Berrimah. (ABC News: Michael Donnelly)The overflow of prisoners is playing out in the courts. More than 185 court matters were listed between just two sitting judges at Darwin Local Court on Tuesday, giving judges about three minutes on average to process each matter. Mr Finn said the NT government had failed to support its tough-on-crime agenda with appropriate infrastructure to cope with rising prisoner numbers. This government continues to beat its chest about locking up more offenders, but it has utterly failed to plan for the consequences of its own policies, he said.Mr Finn also claimed overcrowding inside watch houses was preventing police officers from making arrests. We've heard from a number of members coming through that limitations in watch house space has led to arrests not being made, he said.Gerard Maley said individuals need to stop breaking the law . (ABC News: Pete Garnish)In a statement, Mr Maley said while the government was working to expand corrections infrastructure as quickly as possible , there was no alternative to currently keeping prisoners in watch houses. Police will continue arresting those who break the law, and corrections will continue expanding capacity to ensure those who are remanded or sentenced have a bed, he said. An extra 238 beds are expected to be operational at the Berrimah Correctional Centre by mid-August. That's in addition to the more than 500 new beds in Darwin and Alice Springs that the CLP has delivered since taking office last August. A department spokesperson said correctional staff have not operated out of the Palmerston police watch house since mid-March.LoadingPosted Tue 15 Jul 2025 at 8:19amTuesday 15 Jul 2025 at 8:19amTue 15
